case_name: Seth Fateh Chand v. Lala Balkishan Das

facts.text: Delhi Improvement Trust granted leasehold rights for 90 years to Dr. M. Joshi by registered deed dated May 19, 1927, renewed on January 30, 1947, for plot No. 3, E Block Qarol Bagh, Delhi, 2433 sq. yards.

anchor.surface_text: By a registered deed of lease dated May 19, 1927, which was renewed on January 30, 1947, the Delhi Improvement Trust granted leasehold rights for 90 years to one Dr. M. Joshi in respect of a plot of land No. 3, E Block Qarol Bagh, Delhi, admeasuring 2433 sq. yards.

facts.text: Dr. M. Joshi constructed a building on the leased land.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Joshi companystructed a building on the land demised to him.

facts.text: Chandrawati, widow of Dr. Joshi and guardian of minor son Murli Manohar, sold leasehold rights and building to Lala Balkishan Das (plaintiff) by sale-deed dated April 21, 1947 for Rs. 63,000.

anchor.surface_text: Chandrawati, widow of Dr. Joshi, as guardian of her minor son Murli Manohar, by sale-deed dated April 21, 1947, sold the leasehold rights in the land together with the building to Lala Balkishan Daswho will hereinafter be referred to as the plaintifffor Rs. 63,000/-

facts.text: Plaintiff agreed to sell leasehold rights, land and building to defendant Seth Fateh Chand by agreement dated March 21, 1949 for Rs. 1,12,500, with Rs. 1,000 earnest money paid.

anchor.surface_text: By an agreement dated March 21, 1949-the plaintiff companytracted to sell this rights in the land and the building to Seth Fateh Chand-hereinafter called the defendant. It was recited in the agreement that the plaintiff agreed to sell the building together with pattern rights appertaining to the land admeasuring 2433 sq. yards for Rs. 1,12,500/-, and that Rs. 1,000/- wire paid to him as earnest money at the time of the execution of the agreement.

facts.text: Agreement stipulated delivery of vacant possession on March 30, 1949, payment of Rs. 24,000 by cheque, registration of sale deed by June 1, 1949; forfeiture of Rs. 25,000 if vendee fails.

anchor.surface_text: The companyditions of the agreement were I, the executant, shall deliver the actual possession, i. e. companyplete vacant possession of kothi  bungalow  to the vendee on March 30, 1949, and the vendee shall have to give another cheque for Rs. 24,000/- to me, out of the sale price. Then the vendee shall have to get the sale  deed  registered by the 1st of June, 1949. If, on account of any reason, the vendee fails to get the said sale-deed registered by June, 1949, then this sum of Rs. 25,000/-  twenty-five thousand  mentioned above shall be deemed to be forfeited and the agreement cancelled.

facts.text: Southern boundary of land described in agreement as Bungalow of Murli Manohar Joshi.

anchor.surface_text: The southern boundary of the land was described in the agreement Bungalow of Murli Manohar Joshi.

facts.text: On March 25, 1949, plaintiff received Rs. 24,000 and delivered possession of building and land to defendant.

anchor.surface_text: On March 25, 1949, the plaintiff received Rs. 24,000/- and delivered possession of the building and the land in his occupation to the defendant,

facts.text: Sale not completed before expiry of period in agreement; each party blamed the other.

anchor.surface_text: but the sale of the property was number companypleted before the expiry of the period stipulated in the agreement. Each party blamed the other for failing to companyplete the sale according to the terms of the agreement.

facts.text: Plaintiff filed suit in Subordinate Judge, Delhi, for possession, Rs. 6,500 compensation for use from March 25, 1949 to January 24, 1950, and inquiry for future mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: Alleging that the agreement was rescinded because the defendant had companymitted default in performing the agreement and the sum of Rs. 25,000/- paid by the defendant stood forfeited, the plaintiff in an action filed in the Court of the Subordinate judge, Delhi, claimed a decree for possession of the land and building described in the plaint and a decree for Rs. 6,5001 as companypensation for use and occupation of the building from March 25, 1949, to January 24, 1950, and for an order directing enquiry as to companypensation for use and occupation of the land and building from the date of the institution of the suit until delivery of possession to the plaintiff.

facts.text: Defendant resisted claiming plaintiff breached contract and could not forfeit Rs. 25,000 or claim compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant resisted the claim companytending inter alia that the plaintiff having companymitted breach of the companytract companyld number forfeit the amount of Rs. 25,000/received by him number claim any companypensation.

facts.text: Trial judge held plaintiff failed to put defendant in possession of agreed land, could not retain Rs. 25,000; directed deposit Rs. 25,000 less Rs. 1,400 mesne profits prior to suit, possession to plaintiff, future mesne Rs. 140 per month up to 3 years.

anchor.surface_text: The trial judge held that the plaintiff bad failed to put the defendant in possession of the land agreed to be sold and companyld number therefore retain Rs. 25,000/received by him under the companytract. He accordingly directed that on the plaintiff depositing Rs. 25,000/less Rs. 1,400/-  being the amount of mesne profits prior to the date of the suit  the defendant do put the plaintiff in possession of the land and the building, and awarded to the plaintiff future mesne pro- fits at the rate of Rs. 140/- per mensem from the date of the suit until delivery of possession or until expiration of three years from the date of the decree whichever event first occurred.

facts.text: Punjab High Court modified: plaintiff entitled to retain Rs. 11,250 out of Rs. 25,000 as compensation, mesne profits Rs. 265 per month.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the High Court of Punjab modified the decree passed by the trial Court and declared that the plaintiff was entitled to retain out of Rs. 25,000/- paid by the defendant under the sale agreement, a sum of Rs. 11,250/- being companypensation for loss suffered by him and directed that the plaintiff do get from the defendant companypensation for use and occupation at the rate of Rs. 265/- per mensem.

facts.text: Defendant appealed to Supreme Court with certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant has appealed to this Court with certificate under Art. 133 1  a  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court held defendant committed breach of contract, not plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: We have been taken through the relevant evidence by companynsel and we agree with the companyclusion of the High Court that the defendant and number the plaintiff companymitted breach of the companytract.

facts.text: Defendant claimed plaintiff agreed to sell per Improvement Trust plan, promised to demarcate southern boundary and build wall; did not show documents at agreement time; discovered shortage on south after possession.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants case on the other hand was that the plaintiff had agreed to sell the area according to the measurement and boundaries in the plan annexed to the lease granted by the Improvement Trust and had promised to have the southern boundary demarcated and to have a boundary wall built, that at the time of the execution of the agreement of sale the plaintiff did number show him the sale deed by which he had purchased the property, number the lease obtained from the Improvement Trust in favour of Dr. Joshi number even the sketch plan,

facts.text: Commissioner measured land delivered as 141/142 feet by 157/158 feet; area exceeded 2433 sq. yards; southern boundary irregular due to latrine and garage on adjacent Joshi property.

anchor.surface_text: At the request of the plaintiff the trial Court appointed a Commissioner for measuring the land of which possession was delivered to the defendant, and according to the Commissioner the land admeasured 141/142 feet by 157/158 feet. The Commissioner found, that two companystructions-a latrine and a garage-on the adjacent property belonging to Murli Manohar Joshi broke the regular line of the southern boundary.

facts.text: Defendant first claimed encroachment by Murli Manohar Joshi in letter dated June 17, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants case that a part of the land agreed to be companyveyed was in the possession of Murli Manohar Joshi was set up for the first time by the defendant in his letter dated June 17, 1949.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Rs. 1,000 earnest money forfeitable, but Rs. 24,000 not earnest, stipulation by way of penalty under S.74 Contract Act; no proof of loss beyond earnest and use of money.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant has companyceded that the plaintiff was entitled to forfeit the amount of Rs. 1,000/- which was paid as earnest money. We cannot however agree with the High Court that 10 per cent of the price may be regarded as reasonable companypensation in relation to the value of the companytract as a whole,

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court award of Rs. 11,250 damages; plaintiff retains only Rs. 1,000.

anchor.surface_text: The decree passed by the High Court awarding Rs. 11,250/- as damages to the plaintiff must therefore be set aside.

facts.text: Supreme Court awarded mesne profits at Rs. 140 per mensem from June 1, 1949 till delivery of possession (max 3 years from decree) with 6% interest.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, direct that the mesne profits be companyputed at the rate of Rs. 140/per mensem from June 1, 1949 till the date on which possession was delivered to the plaintiff  such period number exceeding three years from the date of decree  together with interest at the rate of six percent on the amount accruing due month after month.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated August 22, 1957 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Civil Regular First Appeal No. 37-D of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 22, 1957 of the Punjab High Court in  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Civil Regular First Appeal No. 37-D of 1960.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 15, 1963 by Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. January 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-
certificate under Art. 133 1  a  of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The claim made by the plaintiff to forfeit the amount of Rs. 24,000/- may be adjudged in the light of s. 74 of the Indian Contract Act, which in its material part provides - When a companytract has been broken, if a sum is named in the companytract as the amount to be paid in case of such breach, or if the companytract companytains any other stipulation by way of penalty, the party companyplaining of the breach is entitled, whether or number actual damage or loss is proved to have been caused thereby, to receive from the party who has broken the companytract reasonable companypensation number exceeding the amount so named or, as the case maybe, the penalty stipulated for.

concepts.interpretation: Applies to forfeiture of amounts already paid or deposited under contract; eliminates English common law distinction between liquidated damages and penalties; permits reasonable compensation not exceeding stipulated amount even without proof of actual loss, but only where legal injury results; court must award based on settled principles considering circumstances.

holdings.text: The defendant and not the plaintiff committed breach of the contract.

anchor.surface_text: We have been taken through the relevant evidence by companynsel and we agree with the companyclusion of the High Court that the defendant and number the plaintiff companymitted breach of the companytract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court reviewed evidence, agreed with High Court; defendant's claims of shortage and oral promises not in written agreement, no timely written protest despite possession and payment, area delivered exceeded 2433 sq. yards within described boundaries.

holdings.text: The plaintiff was entitled to forfeit the amount of Rs. 1,000 which was paid as earnest money.

anchor.surface_text: Rs.1,000/- received on March 21, 1949 and referred to in the agreement as earnest money

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defendant conceded; expressly named as earnest in agreement, distinct from part payment, forfeitable on buyer's breach without invoking S.74.

holdings.text: The amount of Rs. 24,000 was not of the nature of earnest money.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the Attorney- General that the amount of Rs. 24,000/- was not of the nature of earnest money. The agreement expressly provided for payment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement expressly named only Rs.1,000 as earnest; Rs.24,000 paid out of sale price on delivery of possession, not as security.

holdings.text: Section 74 of the Indian Contract Act applies to stipulations for forfeiture of amounts deposited or paid under the contract.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the expression the contract contains any other stipulation by way of penalty comprehensively applies to every covenant involving a penalty whether it is for payment on breach of contract of money or delivery of property in future, or for forfeiture of right to money or other property already delivered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text covers all penalty stipulations including forfeiture; rejects High Court views limiting to future payments; uniform principle eliminates English distinctions.

holdings.text: In absence of proof of damage, reasonable compensation limited to forfeited earnest money Rs.1,000 and advantage from use of Rs.24,000; High Court award of Rs.11,250 set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The decree passed by the High Court awarding Rs. 11,250/- as damages to the plaintiff must therefore be set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of loss beyond earnest forfeiture and use of money during period; High Court 10% arbitrary; S.74 requires reasonable compensation based on proof even without actual loss if legal injury.

holdings.text: Plaintiff entitled to mesne profits at Rs.140 per mensem from June 1, 1949 till delivery of possession (not exceeding 3 years from decree) with 6% interest on accruing amounts.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, direct that the mesne profits be companyputed at the rate of Rs. 140/per mensem from June 1, 1949 till the date on which possession was delivered to the plaintiff  such period number exceeding three years from the date of decree  together with interest at the rate of six percent on the amount accruing due month after month.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial court rate Rs.140 not shown excessive by defendant; High Court 5% of property value erroneous as mesne profits measure value of user to possessor per S.2(12) CPC, not return on value; add interest.

holdings.text: Mesne profits are profits which the person in wrongful possession actually received or might with ordinary diligence have received, together with interest; normal measure is value of user to possessor.

anchor.surface_text: mesne profits as defined in s. 2  12  of the Code of Civil Procedure are profits which the person in wrongful possession of property actually received or might with ordinary diligence have received therefrom, together with interest on such profits,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of S.2(12) CPC definition; rejects High Court method based on % of property value.

holdings.text: High Court assessment of mesne profits at 5% of property value unsustainable.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment made by the High Court of companypensation at the rate of five per cent of what they regarded as the fair value of the property is based number on the value of the user, but on an estimated return on the value of the property, cannot be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mesne profits based on user value to wrongful possessor, not estimated return on property value.

precedents.citation: Abdul Gani Co. v. Trustees of the Port of Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: In Abdul Gani Co. v. Trustees of the Port of Bombay 1 , the Bombay High Court observed as follows - It will be noticed that the sum which is named in the contract either as penalty or as liquidated damages is a sum which has not already been paid but is to be paid in case of a breach of the contract. With regard to the stipulation by way of penalty, the Legislature has chosen , to qualify stipulation as any other stipulation. indicating that the stipulation must be of the nature of an amount to be paid and not an amount already I.L.R. 1952 Bom. 747.

precedents.case_name: Abdul Gani Co. v. Trustees of the Port of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Section 74 of the Indian Contract Act applies only to sums named to be paid in case of breach or other stipulations for future payment by way of penalty, and not to forfeiture of amounts already paid under the contract
precedents.cited_holding: the sum which is named in the contract either as penalty or as liquidated damages is a sum which has not already been paid but is to be paid in case of a breach of the contract [...] indicating that the stipulation must be of the nature of an amount to be paid and not an amount already paid prior to the entering into of the contract

anchor.surface_text: In Natesa Aiyar v. Appavu Padeyschi 1 , the Madras High Court seems to have held that s. 74 applies where a sum is named as penalty to be paid in future in case of breach, and not to cases where a sum is already paid and by a covenant in the contract it is liable to forfeiture. In these cases the High Courts appear to have concentrated upon the words to be paid in case of such breach in the first condition in s. 74 and did not consider the import of the expression the contract contains any other stipulation by way of penalty, which is the second condition mentioned in the section. 1 1913 I.L.R. 38 Mad. 178.

precedents.cited_proposition: Section 74 applies where a sum is named as penalty to be paid in future in case of breach, and not to cases where a sum is already paid and liable to forfeiture by a covenant in the contract

anchor.surface_text: The decree passed by the High Court will therefore be modified. It is ordered that the plaintiff is entitled to retain out of Rs. 25,000/- only Rs. 1,000/received by him as earnest money, and that he is entitled to companypensation at the rate of Rs. 140/- per mensem and interest on that sum at the rate of six percent as it accrues due month after month from June 1, 1949, till the date of delivery of possession, subject to the restriction prescribed by O,20 r. 12  i   c  of the Code of Civil Procedure.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court decree modified: plaintiff can retain only Rs. 1,000 earnest money from Rs. 25,000; mesne profits at Rs. 140 per mensem plus 6% interest from June 1, 1949 till delivery of possession (subject to O.20 r.12(c) CPC); appeal dismissed subject to these modifications
directions: Plaintiff entitled to retain Rs. 1,000/- earnest money out of Rs. 25,000/-
Mesne profits and interest at Rs. 140/- per mensem + 6% from June 1, 1949 till delivery of possession, not exceeding 3 years from decree date
Parties to bear their own costs in this Court

In our judgment the expression the contract contains any other stipulation by way of penalty comprehensively applies to every covenant involving a penalty whether it is for payment on breach of contract of money or delivery of property in future, or for forfeiture of right to money or other property already delivered.
